subject: Re: [junit] problems due to lack of annotation inheritance for methods

messageBody:
On 6/28/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
>
> You've had to do _this_ (a compile-time check that every test class has
> a @Before method), or something else that also involves annotations and
> inheritance?


The latter.

Imagine that you are writing a bunch of test methods that should all belong
to the group "database". Instead of having to do this for every single
method, you do it on the class and the annotation applies to all the public
methods of your class:

@Test(groups = {"database"})
public void DataBaseTest {
public void test1() { ... }
public void test2() { ... }
}

That's not bad, but if somebody creates a new test class, they still need to
remember to put the annotation at the class level.

Enter inheritance:

@Test(groups = {"database"})
public class BaseDataBaseTest {
}

public void DataBaseTest extends BaseDataBaseTest {
public void test1() { ... }
public void test2() { ... }
}

public void DataBase2Test extends BaseDataBaseTest {
public void test3() { ... }
public void test4() { ... }
}

Notice something? The child test classes are pure POJO's! No annotations
anywhere, no potential for error. Just tell the developers in your team to
extend that class that contains the base annotations and the entire set up
is done for them automatically.
